The American Girl is one such novel . . . a remarkable read' Real reader review, ⭐ ⭐ ⭐ ⭐ ⭐______Inspired by heartbreaking true events in a home for unwed mothers, journeying from Boston to Ireland, the No.1 bestselling novel The American Girl is a heartrending and captivating story of mothers and daughters, love and cruelty, and the triumph of hope.Boston 1968. Rose Moroney is seventeen, smart, spirited - and pregnant. She wants to marry her boyfriend but her ambitious parents have other plans. She is sent to Ireland, their birthplace, to deliver her daughter in a home for unwed mothers - and part with her against her will.Dublin 2013. Martha Sheeran's life has come undone. Her marriage is over, and her husband has moved on with unsettling speed. Under pressure from her teenage daughter, she starts looking for the woman who gave her up for adoption more than forty years before.As her search leads her to the heart of long-buried family secrets, an old flame also re-enters her life. Can the future offer an unexpected new beginning?*THE LETTER HOME, THE NEW NOVEL FROM RACHAEL ENGLISH, IS AVAILABLE NOW*______Your favourite authors love the novels of Rachael English:'Utterly moving and compelling. reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Really good book, Rachel English never disappoints. Interesting reversal of her other book, The Paper Bracelet. A truly enjoyable read, highly recommended.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 16, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Speak up Rose!
reviews.reviewText: I liked the book. I also thought the ending was a bit abrupt. It annoyed me that everyone berated Rose at the end with self righteous indignation and victimized her all over again. She was forced to make promises to her parents, the miserable, controlling nuns, and ever her husband; promises she kept because they had all the control and she was too broken to defy them. When it all came out in the end she was berated for.keeping secrets others forced her to keep. I would have been much happier if she had told them all to sod off. They weren't the one who was exiled, tormented, and buried under guilt and cruelty. Joe especially irritated me. He seemed very smug in his anger. He didn't express any remorse for not trying harder to reach out to her when she returned from Ireland. He blew her off.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2024
reviews.reviewText: One secret after another is revealed in this heartbreaking novel. It is so sad to think things like this actually happened. It was definitely an excellent, well told story.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Lifelong torment for one parent. Unawareness of the truth by the other. Their child in limbo.
reviews.reviewText: I actually feel the novel is overloaded with too many side stories. The result is constantly jumping from one character to another. Also, the ending is rather abrupt.

reviews.reviewText: Are you required to swear to tell the absolute truth at all times? I am not sure but I have the feeling that’s the way it has to be! I’m convinced that the lives of my family members are connected and interconnected. They just can’t survive with false hopes. Think of how wonderful these lives can be

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Enjoyed this story, it was well written, flowed nicely. Showed the many realistic struggles of the characters involved. I was anxious to finish reading to see how it all turned out. Definitely would recommend.
What a great read and so realistic to what some adoptees and birth parents went through back in that era.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on June 12, 2018
reviews.reviewText: I absolutely loved reading this book and found that it was a bit of a page turner. Admittedly I do have an interest in the Magdalene Laundries after watching the movie The Magdalene Sisters and then latterly Philomena and discovering that the Catholic school I attended as a small girl was run by one of the orders involved.Despite what could be a very dour topic - forced adoption, there is a lightness of touch and humour in this book and an attempt at showing the laundries for what they were whilst glossing over the main atrocities. The bulk of the novel is set in the modern day cities of Dublin and Boston and Carrigbrack is mentioned only briefly but it looms large over the rest of the tale.Martha Sheeran has always known she was adopted, her parents have been open about that much at least. However, it seems there is an unwarranted amount of secrecy surrounding the adoption and as her daughter reaches the outer reaches of childhood and with her marriage broken down she decides to look for her birth parents. We experience the highs and lows of the search and the impact it has on her friendships and family relationships when Martha unearths more than she expected.The pace of the tale is gentle and we experience everything through the voices of Martha and her birth mother Rose. Things that were considered dead and buried come to light thanks to the efforts of both of their respective children once the truth starts to become known will either of their lives ever be the same again?The sense of time and place, particularly in the late 1960s, is exquisitely realised and I did feel completely drawn in to this rather peculiar world of moral standards and appearance being all. The characterisations are well drawn and the people inhabiting the book soon begin to feel real to the reader and you find yourself wishing he best for them whilst shaking your head at some of their decisions.Definitely an author I will be reading more from!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the Netherlands on February 7, 2018
reviews.reviewText: this is one of the best books I have read in a long time. could not put it down. brilliant
The story ended and it’s conclusion was good but it left me wishing for the story to continue. I think this is a sign of good author. You will be intrigued until the very end and wanting more.
